column1: What is DNS?
column2: Domain Name System - a system for resolving computer names into IP addresses without a central database

column1: How many DNS root servers are there globally?
column2: 13 root servers around the globe

column1: What organization coordinates the work of DNS root name servers?
column2: ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers)

column1: What is the difference between authoritative and non-authoritative name servers?
column2: Authoritative name servers hold authority for a particular zone and their information is binding. Non-authoritative name servers are not responsible for a particular DNS zone and collect information using recursive or iterative DNS querying

column1: What are the main DNS encryption solutions mentioned?
column2: DNS over TLS (DoT), DNS over HTTPS (DoH), and DNSCrypt

column1: What does an A record return?
column2: Returns an IPv4 address of the requested domain

column1: What does an AAAA record return?
column2: Returns an IPv6 address of the requested domain

column1: What does an MX record return?
column2: Returns the responsible mail servers

column1: What does an NS record return?
column2: Returns the DNS servers (nameservers) of the domain

column1: What can a TXT record contain?
column2: Various information including Google Search Console validation, SSL certificate validation, SPF and DMARC entries for mail traffic validation

column1: What is a CNAME record used for?
column2: Serves as an alias for another domain name

column1: What does a PTR record do?
column2: Works in reverse - converts IP addresses into valid domain names (reverse lookup)

column1: What information does an SOA record provide?
column2: Provides information about the corresponding DNS zone and email address of the administrative contact

column1: What are the three types of DNS configuration files?
column2: Local DNS configuration files, zone files, and reverse name resolution files

column1: What is the most commonly used DNS server on Linux distributions?
column2: Bind9

column1: What are the main Bind9 configuration files?
column2: named.conf.local, named.conf.options, named.conf.log

column1: What is a zone file?
column2: A text file that describes a DNS zone with the BIND file format - it's a point of delegation in the DNS tree

column1: What must every zone file contain?
column2: Precisely one SOA record and at least one NS record

column1: What is the purpose of reverse name resolution files?
column2: To resolve IP addresses to Fully Qualified Domain Names (FQDN) using PTR records

column1: What does the allow-query option define?
column2: Defines which hosts are allowed to send requests to the DNS server

column1: What does the allow-recursion option define?
column2: Defines which hosts are allowed to send recursive requests to the DNS server

column1: What does the allow-transfer option define?
column2: Defines which hosts are allowed to receive zone transfers from the DNS server

column1: What command is used to query DNS NS records?
column2: dig ns domain.com @dns-server

column1: What command can be used to query DNS server version?
column2: dig CH TXT version.bind dns-server-ip

column1: What command shows all available DNS records?
column2: dig any domain.com @dns-server

column1: What does AXFR stand for?
column2: Asynchronous Full Transfer Zone

column1: What port is typically used for DNS zone transfers?
column2: TCP port 53

column1: What command performs a zone transfer?
column2: dig axfr domain.com @dns-server

column1: What is the difference between a master and slave DNS server?
column2: A master serves as a direct source for synchronizing a zone file, while a slave obtains zone data from a master

column1: What is a primary DNS server?
column2: The DNS server where the original data of a zone is located - always a master

column1: What is a secondary DNS server?
column2: Additional servers installed to increase reliability and load distribution - can be both slave and master

column1: What tool can be used for DNS subdomain brute forcing?
column2: DNSenum

column1: What is the refresh time for DNS slaves to check SOA records?
column2: Usually one hour

column1: What happens when a DNS slave's SOA serial number is lower than the master's?
column2: The data sets no longer match and synchronization is needed

column1: What security risk does unencrypted DNS pose?
column2: Devices on local WLAN and Internet providers can intercept and spy on DNS queries

column1: What is the purpose of the rndc-key?
column2: A secret key that ensures DNS servers communicate with their own master or slave
